Function.Name: Loss (Functions)
Function.Description: Quantify the error between predicted and actual values during model training.
Function.InputData: A single numerical value representing the loss
Function.Role: Loss functions quantify the difference between predicted and actual values in machine learning models. They are crucial for training models by providing a measure of error that the optimization algorithm aims to minimize.

Function.Name: L1 Loss (Mean Absolute Error)
Function.Description: Calculates the average of the absolute differences between predictions and actual values. Robust to outliers.
Function.InputData: A single numerical value representing the mean absolute error
Function.Properties: Robust to outliers, non-differentiable at zero, linear growth
Function.Purpose: Regression models, models where robustness to outliers is important
Function.Role: L1 Loss, also known as Mean Absolute Error (MAE), calculates the average of the absolute differences between predictions and true values. It is less sensitive to outliers compared to L2 loss.

Function.Name: L2 Loss (Mean Squared Error)
Function.Description: Calculates the average of the squared differences between predictions and actual values. Penalizes large errors more heavily than L1 loss.
Function.InputData: A single numerical value representing the mean squared error
Function.Properties: Sensitive to outliers, differentiable, quadratic growth
Function.Role: L2 Loss, also known as Mean Squared Error (MSE), calculates the average of the squared differences between predictions and true values. It penalizes larger errors more heavily than L1 loss, making it sensitive to outliers.

Function.Name: Probability (Sigmoid Function)
Function.Description: Converts any real value to a probability between 0 and 1. Used in binary classification problems.
Function.Role: The Sigmoid function is an activation function that maps any real-valued number to a probability between 0 and 1. It is commonly used in binary classification problems to model the probability of a data point belonging to a particular class.

Function.Name: Loss (Log Loss)
Function.Description: Measures the performance of a classification model where the prediction input is a probability value between 0 and 1.
Function.InputData: A single numerical value representing the log loss
Function.Properties: Differentiable, non-negative, increases sharply as prediction deviates from actual
Function.Purpose: Binary and multi-class classification models, logistic regression, neural networks
Function.Role: Log Loss, also known as Binary Cross-Entropy Loss, measures the performance of a classification model where the prediction input is a probability value between 0 and 1. It is particularly suitable for binary classification tasks.

Function.Name: Activation Functions (Types)
Function.Description: Introduce non-linearity to neural networks, enabling them to learn complex patterns.
Function.OutputData: Weighted sum of inputs from the previous layer
Function.Properties: Introduce non-linearity, differentiable (most), can affect gradient flow
Function.Role: Activation functions introduce non-linearity into neural networks, enabling them to learn complex patterns. Different types of activation functions have varying Purpose that affect the training dynamics and performance of the network.

Function.Name: Sigmoid-family (Sigmoid, Tanh)
Function.Description: A group of activation functions that includes Sigmoid and Tanh, known for their 'S' shape.
Function.Properties: Differentiable, saturating non-linearity, can suffer from vanishing gradients
Function.Purpose: Historically in neural networks, recurrent neural networks (RNNs)
Function.Role: The Sigmoid family includes activation functions like Sigmoid and Tanh, which produce 'S' shaped curves. They were historically popular but can suffer from vanishing gradients in deep networks.

Function.Name: ReLU-family (ReLU, ReLU6, Leaky ReLU, ELU)
Function.Description: A group of activation functions based on the Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU), designed to address the vanishing gradient problem.
Function.InputData: Non-negative value (with variations for Leaky ReLU and ELU)
Function.Properties: Computationally efficient, can suffer from dying ReLU (except Leaky ReLU, ELU)
Function.Purpose: Modern neural networks, convolutional neural networks (CNNs)
Function.Role: The ReLU family is based on the Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU). These functions are designed to address the vanishing gradient problem and are widely used in modern neural networks due to their efficiency.

Function.Name: Other (Softmax, etc)
Function.Description: Activation functions that don't fall into the Sigmoid or ReLU families, such as Softmax.
Function.Purpose: Softmax: Multi-class classification models, neural networks
Function.Role: This category includes activation functions that don't fall into the Sigmoid or ReLU families. Softmax, for example, is used in multi-class classification to produce a probability distribution over multiple classes.

Function.Name: Activation Functions (Types and Pros/Cons)
Function.Description: Overview of different activation functions, discussing their advantages and disadvantages.
Function.Role: This entry provides an overview of different activation functions, discussing their advantages, disadvantages, and typical use cases. It helps in selecting the appropriate activation function for a given neural network architecture.

Function.Name: Sigmoid-family
Function.Description: Activation functions that produce 'S' shaped curves.
Function.Role: This refers to the family of activation functions that produce an 'S' shaped curve, with Sigmoid and Tanh being the most common members.

Function.Name: Sigmoid
Function.Description: Squashes values between 0 and 1, historically popular for binary classification.
Function.Properties: Bounded output, historically used for binary classification
Function.Role: The Sigmoid function squashes values between 0 and 1, making it suitable for binary classification problems where the output represents a probability.

Function.Name: Tanh
Function.Description: Squashes values between -1 and 1, similar to Sigmoid but centered at 0.
Function.Role: The Hyperbolic Tangent (Tanh) function is similar to Sigmoid but squashes values between -1 and 1. It is zero-centered, which can be advantageous in some neural network architectures.

Function.Name: ReLU-family
Function.Description: Activation functions that activate neurons only if the input is above a certain threshold.
Function.Role: This family of activation functions is based on the Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU) and its variants, designed to mitigate the vanishing gradient problem.

Function.Name: ReLU
Function.Description: Outputs the input directly if it is positive, otherwise outputs zero. Simple and efficient.
Function.Properties: Simple, efficient, can lead to dying ReLU
Function.Role: The Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU) is a simple and efficient activation function that outputs the input directly if it is positive and zero otherwise.

Function.Name: ReLU6
Function.Description: A variant of ReLU that clips the output at 6, useful in some hardware-constrained environments.
Function.Properties: Bounded ReLU, useful for quantized networks
Function.Role: ReLU6 is a variant of ReLU that clips the output at 6. It is sometimes used in mobile or embedded applications where computational efficiency is crucial.

Function.Name: Leaky ReLU
Function.Description: Allows a small, non-zero gradient when the unit is not active, mitigating the dying ReLU problem.
Function.Properties: Avoids dying ReLU, introduces small non-zero gradient
Function.Role: Leaky ReLU addresses the dying ReLU problem by allowing a small, non-zero gradient when the unit is not active. This helps in better gradient flow during training.

Function.Name: ELU
Function.Description: Exponential Linear Unit. Aims to speed up learning by reducing the bias shift effect.
Function.InputData: Value, allowing negative values with exponential decay
Function.Properties: Smooth, can speed up learning, computationally intensive
Function.Role: The Exponential Linear Unit (ELU) is another variant of ReLU that aims to speed up learning by reducing the bias shift effect. It allows for negative values, which can push the mean activation closer to zero.

Function.Name: Softmax
Function.Description: Converts a vector of numbers into a vector of probabilities, where the probabilities sum to 1. Used in multi-class classification.
Function.Properties: Normalizes outputs to a probability distribution
Function.Role: The Softmax function converts a vector of numbers into a probability distribution, where the probabilities sum to 1. It is commonly used in the output layer of multi-class classification models.

Function.Name: Swish/SiLU
Function.Description: A relatively new activation function defined as x * sigmoid(x).
Function.Role: Swish and SiLU (Sigmoid Linear Unit) are relatively new activation functions that have shown promising results in deep learning models. Swish is defined as f(x) = x * sigmoid(x).

Function.Name: GELU
Function.Description: Gaussian Error Linear Unit. A smooth approximation to the ReLU function.
Function.Role: The Gaussian Error Linear Unit (GELU) is a smooth approximation to the ReLU function. It has shown excellent performance in transformer models.

Function.Name: Functions
Function.Description: General Formula methods or operations.
Function.OutputData: Varies depending on the specific function
Function.InputData: Varies depending on the specific function
Function.Role: This category refers to general-Formula methods or operations that perform specific tasks, such as data manipulation or object conversion.

Function.Name: serialize
Function.Description: Convert an object into a stream of bytes to store it or transmit it over a network.
Function.Role: Serialization is the process of converting an object into a format that can be stored or transmitted, such as a stream of bytes.

Function.Name: deserialize
Function.Description: Convert a stream of bytes back into an object.
Function.Role: Deserialization is the reverse process of serialization, where a serialized object is converted back into its original form.

Function.Name: get
Function.Description: Retrieve a specific element or value from a collection or data structure.
Function.Role: The 'get' function is a common operation in programming that retrieves a specific element or value from a collection or data structure based on a key or index.

Function.Name: elu
Function.Description: Alias for the Exponential Linear Unit activation function.
Function.Role: This is an alias for the Exponential Linear Unit (ELU) activation function.

Function.Name: exponential
Function.Description: Mathematical function that calculates e raised to the power of a number.
Function.Properties: Rapid growth, defined for all real numbers
Function.Role: The exponential function is a mathematical function that calculates e (Euler's number) raised to the power of a given number.

Function.Name: hard_sigmoid
Function.Description: A piecewise linear approximation of the sigmoid function. Faster to compute.
Function.Role: Hard Sigmoid is a piecewise linear approximation of the Sigmoid function. It is computationally more efficient than Sigmoid but less smooth.

Function.Name: hard_silu
Function.Description: A computationally efficient approximation of the SiLU activation function.
Function.Role: Hard SiLU is a computationally efficient approximation of the SiLU activation function.

Function.Name: hard_swish
Function.Description: A computationally efficient approximation of the Swish activation function.
Function.Role: Hard Swish is a computationally efficient approximation of the Swish activation function.

Function.Name: linear
Function.Description: A linear (identity) activation function, often used in the output layer for regression.
Function.Purpose: Linear regression, output layers of regression models
Function.Role: The linear activation function, also known as the identity function, simply outputs the input without any transformation. It is often used in the output layer for regression problems.

Function.Name: log_softmax
Function.Description: Computes the logarithm of the Softmax function.
Function.Properties: Numerical stability, combines log and softmax
Function.Role: Log Softmax is a function that computes the logarithm of the Softmax function. It is often used in classification tasks for numerical stability.

Function.Name: mish
Function.Description: A self-regularizing non-monotonic activation function.
Function.Role: Mish is a self-regularizing non-monotonic activation function that has shown promising results in various deep learning tasks.

Function.Name: selu
Function.Description: Scaled Exponential Linear Unit. Induces self-normalizing Purpose.
Function.Role: Scaled Exponential Linear Unit (SELU) is an activation function that induces self-normalizing Purpose in neural networks, helping to stabilize training.

Function.Name: softplus
Function.Description: A smooth approximation to the ReLU function.
Function.Role: Softplus is a smooth approximation to the ReLU function. It is differentiable everywhere and outputs only positive values.

Function.Name: softsign
Function.Description: A function that outputs a value between -1 and 1, similar to tanh but with slower growth.
Function.Role: Softsign is an activation function that outputs a value between -1 and 1. It is similar to Tanh but has a slower growth rate.
